thread.title: 'Safe' New Year in UK despite security fears
thread.title_full: 'Safe' New Year in UK despite security fears

title: 'Safe' New Year in UK despite security fears
text:
Weather 'Safe and successful' New Year in UK despite security fears Police are now turning their attention to London's New Year's Day parade, which is set to be attended by 500,000 people later. 04:46, UK, Sunday 01 January 2017 Video: In full: London's 2017 fireworks spectacular Facebook By Connor Sephton, News Reporter London's New Year celebrations have been described as "safe and successful" by police, after 110,000 people gathered along the River Thames to watch a 12-minute fireworks spectacular. 
The Metropolitan Police said its officers had made 33 arrests by 3am - mainly in connection with assaults and public order offences. 
A raft of additional security measures had been put in place on New Year's Eve to protect crowds, including concrete bollards and armed police patrols, amid concerns that London could be susceptible to a terror attack. 
For the first time, armed officers were also deployed on London Underground trains throughout the night. 
British Transport Police said its officers worked extended hours on New Year's Eve for the second year in a row. Image Caption: It took more than three hours to rig the London Eye with fireworks 
After the celebrations came to an end, Detective Superintendent Phil Langworthy said: "Once again, the eyes of the world were on London and a truly spectacular event has been delivered here." 
Although the capital's party animals may have gone home, work to keep London safe hasn't ended - with police working through the night to get the streets back to normal in time for the New Year's Day parade later on. 
More than 500,000 spectators are expected to attend the parade, now in its 31st year, with more than 8,000 performers set to take part in the procession from Piccadilly to Parliament Square. 
Those who managed to get a ticket to London's sold-out event last night won't be forgetting the extravagant fireworks display anytime soon. 
The pyrotechnic extravaganza boasted 12,000 fireworks which produced 50,000 projectiles over 12 minutes - all fired from the London Eye as well as three barges and 14 pontoons on the Thames. 
It cost Â£1.8m to produce, and also featured tributes to some of the beloved stars who died over the past 12 months. Video: London Mayor addresses NYE security concerns 
Before the display began, London Mayor Sadiq Khan had told Sky News: "Our police and security services do an amazing job learning the lessons from some horrific incidents in other cities around the world - Berlin recently, Nice earlier this year, Paris last year. 
"We've got to make sure we don't allow terrorists or people who want to destroy our way of life to stop us enjoying what's going to be a great night." 
Up in Edinburgh, an estimated 80,000 revellers took to the streets for the city's world-renowned Hogmanay celebrations - enjoying three fireworks shows ahead of the Midnight Moment from the ramparts of Edinburgh Castle. 
There was also live music in the Scottish capital from the likes of The Charlatans and Paolo Nutini. Video: Edinburgh celebrates Hogmanay in style 
Even though London's display came hours before the likes of New York and Washington wave goodbye to 2016, Mr Khan confidently said the fireworks would be "the best any city in the world is having tonight". 
But it might be wise to keep an eye on Hull, which is planning a New Year's Day spectacle to rival London's in honour of its new status as City of Culture. Posted in:
